text: the world record for fastest marathon
stands in 2 hours 2 minutes and 57
seconds that doesn't come close to
what's humanly possible human physiology
expert Mike joiner examine human
thresholds for oxygen uptake and lactic
acid buildup and calculated that the
fastest marathon a human could ever run
is 1 hour 57 minutes and 58 seconds but
reaching this limit will require the
right course on the ideal day with the
perfect runner since 1988 runners have
broken the world record 11 times seven
of those world records took place in
Berlin on average runners finish 81
seconds faster and from Lynn and other
races that's likely because the course
is relatively flat and straightened
another key factor is temperature the
researchers have found that the fastest
runners perform best at thirty eight
point nine degrees Fahrenheit which
could explain why over half of the best
marathon time since 2000 were run in
April or September but it's not just the
course it's also the runner it turns out
the perfect runner will likely be
smaller than average elite marathon
times for men went from two hours eleven
minutes and 49 seconds in 1992 two hours
seven minutes and ten seconds in 2011 at
the same time the top 100 male
marathoners went from an average weight
of 131 point four pounds in 1990 and one
hundred twenty three point nine pounds
in 2011 and their average height went up
to five point one inches in 1992 five
feet six point nine inches in 2011 this
likely has to do with the runners body
heat shorter smaller runners produce
less heat
dissipated faster so they overheat less
quickly they can run faster for longer
distances
other factors include endurance
confidence and how efficient a runner is
and delivering oxygen to the muscles
it's a lot of pieces that must fit
together perfectly but perhaps one day
the right runner will compete on the
right track history will be made
